## Microhabitat

> Physical habitat variables measured at each frog

 - [*Quantitative*]{.purple}: local velocity, depth, channel width
 - [*Categorical*]{.purple}: dominant substrate, cover, geomorphic unit, hydraulic unit, reach type, riparian type

::: {.fragment}
![](../img/habitat_breeding_rabo.jpg){.absolute left=0 bottom=0 width=30%}

![](../img/hab_campck02.jpg){.absolute right=0 bottom=0 width=30%}
:::

::: footer
Microhabitat
:::


## Microhabitat Associations 

:::{.incremental}
 - While RABO use a wide array of habitat, local hydraulic conditions are main physical control on breeding and rearing habitat
 - Egg and tadpoles are susceptible to scour / dessication from high velocities or stage drops
 - Predictability and variability (heterogeneity) are important
:::

::: footer
Microhabitat
:::


## Habitat Suitability Criteria {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}

::: {.column .pr4 width="40%" .incremental}

 - Use vs. Available habitat clearly shows preference for low-velocity/depth

 - 90% of eggs observed in Sierras were in shallow, sheltered waters (n=147) (Bondi et al. 2013)
    - < 0.67 m total depth
    - < 0.15 m/s velocity

# Breeding <br> Habitat<br> Details {background-image="../img/storer_1925_egg_drawing.png" background-size="contain" background-position="right" background-color="#000000"}


## Egg Mass Hydrologic Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%" .incremental}

 - [Egg Mass Water Depths:]{.f2 .blue}
    - 10--13 cm (Fitch 1936) 
    - 7--22 cm (Fuller & Lind 1992)
    - 4--43 cm (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997)
    - 6--28 cm (Van Wagner 1996)
    - 6--40 cm (Lind 2005)
    - [\> 2m!]{.red} (Peek, pers. obs. 2017)
    - 90% found in 14--67 cm in Sierras (Yarnell et al. 2011)

:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

![](../img/rabo_eggs_sfy_dark.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

![Butte](../img/hab_breeding_ButteCreek.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

:::
:::

::: footer
Breeding
:::

## Egg Mass Hydrologic Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%" .incremental}

- [**Egg Mass Water Velocities**]{.blue .f2}:
  - 0.0--0.06 m/s (Fuller and Lind 1992)
  - 0.01--0.14 m/s (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997)
  - 0.0--0.03 m/s (Van Wagner 1996)
  - 0.00--0.21 m/s (Lind 2005)
  - 0.04--0.17 m/s (Wheeler and Welsh 2008)
  - Eggs: 90% found in 0.00--0.15 m/s (Yarnell et al. 2011)
 

:::

::: {.column width="40%"}


![](../img/rabo_em_gos09.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

![Eel](../img/hab_breeding_EelRiver.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

:::
:::

::: notes

Substrate: most common – cobbles and boulders, "clean" (no algae/sediment) surface for egg attachment (Kupferberg 1996 & 1997, Van Wagner 1996, Lind 2005, Wheeler et al. 2003)

:::

::: footer
Breeding
:::

## Tadpole Hydrologic Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}
::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {.fragment .mt1}

[**Depths**]{.f2 .blue}

 - Early Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 1--54 cm
 - Late Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 1--51 cm (Yarnell et al. 2011)

:::

::: {.fragment .mt1}

[**Velocities**]{.f2 .blue}

 - Early Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 0.00--0.16 m/s
 - Late Stage Tadpoles (90% within): 0.00--0.12 m/s (Yarnell et al. 2011)
 - Critical velocities ranged from 0.01--0.04 m/s depending on developmental state, body size, and population of origin (Kupferberg et al. 2009)

:::

:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

![](../img/hab_tadpole.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

![](../img/rabo_large_tadpole.jpg){width=80% fig-align="right"}

:::
:::

::: footer
Rearing
:::


## Adult Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.incremental}

 - Most common along pool, glide, or riffles (Lind and Yarnell 2008, Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Yarnell 2005, Van Wagner 1996, Lind 2005)
 - Near stream cover may include wide array from shoreline rocks (especially cobble), to leaf litter, or overhanging vegetation [e.g. Carex sp.] (Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Yarnell 2005, Hayes and Jennings 1988, Van Wagner 1996)
 - Adults may prefer some riparian overhanging vegetation (e.g. Carex sp.) with moderate shade (Van Wagner 1996, Zweifel 1955, Moyle 1973, Hayes and Jennings 1988)

:::

<br>
[**So pretty much all the possibilities!**]{.tc .f1 .blue .fragment}


::: footer
Adults
:::

::: notes

Post-metamorphic R. boylii remain in terrestrial riparian and riverine habitat adjacent to the wetted channel during the non-breeding season (Bourque 2008, Kupferberg 1996, Lind et al. 1996, Moyle 1973, Van Wagner 1996, Zweifel 1955). Rana boylii have been documented in a wide range of habitats, but all generally occur within a short distance of flowing water (see Bourque 2008) although differences appear to vary both regionally and seasonally (Bourque 2008, Haggarty 2006, Van Wagner 1996, Yarnell 2000, Yarnell 2005).

:::

## Overwintering Habitat {.smaller}

::: {.columns .pv4}
::: {.column width="60%" .incremental}
 
 - Very little data are available relating to overwintering habitat
 - Van Wagner (1996) observed *R. boylii* both in the water and along the stream-edge habitat beneath rocks, leaf litter, and *Carex spp*
 - Also found frogs appeared to be active whenever ambient conditions were favorable
 - Habitat use in large rivers may vary, juveniles & adults may move into smaller lateral tributaries to avoid risk of scouring (Kupferberg 1996)
 - Or move into adjacent terrestrial habitat to avoid winter flood events altogether.
 
:::
::: {.column .tc .pv4 width="39%"}
![Cave RABO!](../img/rabo_overwintering.jpg)
:::
:::

::: footer
Overwintering
:::



## Reach Heterogeneity

::: {.columns}

::: {.column .pr4 width="45%"}

 - Compared 10 study reaches, Shannons Diversity Index key predictor of frog abundance (Yarnell 2008)
 - Habitat diversity within a reach matters

:::
::: {.column .pr4 width="55%"}

::: {.r-stack .incremental}

![Yarnell 2008](../img/yarnell_2008_geomorphic_reach_type.png){.fragment width=90%}

![](../img/yarnell_2008_shannons.png){.fragment fig-align="center"}



:::

:::
:::

## Network Heterogeneity { background-image="../img/azimuth_inset_map_nfamerican.png" background-size="cover" background-color="#000000"}

## Network Heterogeneity {.smaller background-image="../img/peek_2010_conf_fig.png" background-size="50%" background-position="right" background-color="#000000"}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column .f2 .pr4 width="45%" .incremental}

 - Not only does the diversity of habitats within a reach matter, but the location of the reach within the stream network matters. 
 - Frogs occur closer to confluences than random or “expected” (Peek 2010)
 - Confluences are known to have higher diversity of habitats and create refugia

:::

:::

::: notes

Frogs associate with stream reaches of greater physical habitat heterogeneity

Analysing the complexity of geomorphic units at the reach scale is appropriate for this species

:::

## Habitat Summary {background-image="../img/habitat_willow_bars.jpg" background-size="cover" background-position="right" background-color="#000000" background-opacity=30%}

::: {.incremental}
 - Different life stages require different [hydraulic]{.light-blue} and [substrate]{.light-yellow} conditions
 - [Hydraulic]{.light-blue} and [substrate]{.light-yellow} conditions characterize mesohabitats (e.g., geomorphic units like riffles, pools)
 - Certain reach types, differentiated by higher diversity of geomorphic units, are preferred by life stages
 - Reaches near tributaries are often preferred because structurally more diverse & provide refugia
:::

::: notes
At RABO XS we see recession rates typically 30cm per 3 weeks (~10 cm a week) no matter the water year. SO stage change is consistent! Makes sense given avg depths for eggs usually 20-40cm, and 2-3 weeks to hatch out.
:::

## Recession Rates

::: {.columns}

::: {.column .pr4 width="40%" .incremental}

![](../img/rabo_tad_bean.jpg)

:::
::: {.column .pr4 width="60%" .incremental}

 - In RABO breeding areas, recession rates are typically 30cm per 3 weeks (~10 cm a week)
 - This is consistent across water years
 - Thus stage change is consistent, matches natural history observations of depth/velocity (hatching timing ~2-3 weeks to hatch out)

:::
:::

## Dams change flow patterns {.smaller background-image="../img/lytle_poff_2004.jpg" background-size="80%" background-position="center" background-color="#FFFFFF"}

:::footer
Lytle and Poff 2004
:::


## Type of flow alteration plays a big role {.smaller background-image="../img/regulation_types_combined.png" background-size="contain" background-position="center" background-color="#000000"}


::: notes

 - Altered flows often aseasonal/asynchronous to natural flow regime
 - Decoupling of flow cues from environmental cues
 - Eggs can be scoured or dessicated by changing flows
 - Changes in algal/insect prey base
 - Tadpole energetic costs to "hunkering down" and issues when refugia not available (bed armoring)

:::
